body: Still Making Deals At a Different Table Years back, Theodore W. Kheel helped settle so many big and bitter labor disputes in New York and around the country that he was widely regarded as the maestro of mediation. These days, he still uses his talent for bringing people together, though for ends other than soothing passions at the bargaining table.
title: FOLLOWING UP

body: TEN years ago, when Karen Brenner first moved to Park Slope, she settled in a rented one-bedroom floor-through on Third Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. In 2001 she moved again. She bought a two-bedroom apartment in a newly built 36-unit condominium called Park Slope Estates on Second Street between Fifth and Fourth Avenues. To outsiders
title: Rezoning, and Redefining, Park Slope

body: Manhattan LOWER EAST SIDE $845,000 7 Essex Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath 1,548-sq.-ft. condo in a pre-World War II building; elevator, dining area, 10-ft. ceilings, hardwood floors, common roof deck; common charge $683; taxes $6,475; listed at $900,000, 8 weeks on market (brokers: Hunie Kwon; J C DeNiro & Associates) GRAMERCY PARK AREA $650,000 21 East
title: RESIDENTIAL SALES

body: WHEN Bridgette Raes woke up this summer covered with red itchy bumps, the last thing she expected was bedbugs. A Manhattan dermatologist told Ms. Raes, a 29-year-old image consultant from Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, that she had scabies, an allergy to a common mite. She tried the Elimite Cream he prescribed, but the red marks continued to appear.
title: Sleeping With the Enemy

body: A four-month battle over a women's shelter planned for Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, intensified this month when its supporters called for a boycott of local businesses that advertise on a Web site that has provided links to the shelter's address. The shelter, which will be known as Rose House and will house battered Asian women and their children, is
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; Boycott Steps Up the Fight Over a Women's Shelter

body: To the Editor: I'm saddened by all the talk of developing Brooklyn. There have been reports that some megacomplex will be built downtown, and now there is the possibility of the new Nets stadium (''A Grand Plan in Brooklyn for the Nets' Arena Complex,'' news article, Dec. 11). For business, this is great. But I moved to Brooklyn because it's not
title: Don't Mess With Brooklyn

body: DAVID BURKE & DONATELLA may sound like a lounge act, but it is the name of the restaurant that Mr. Burke, a chef formerly of the Smith & Wollensky Group, and his partner, DONATELLA ARPAIA , who owns Bellini, are opening at 133 East 61st Street. The two, below, have turned the dark interior of what was Il Valetto into a bright space accented with
title: FOOD STUFF; Off the Menu

body: NEW YORK is an organic creature, capable of lifting your soul skyward one day, then grinding it slowly to powder the next. But who knew that the city manipulated inanimate objects as whimsically as people? I'm talking about my box of old clothes. I recently moved to the south end of Carroll Gardens, a nether region of welding shops and warehouses.
title: URBAN STUDIES/SHEDDING; Another Curbside Attraction

body: THE question haunting Madison Avenue these days is, to paraphrase Sigmund Freud, ''What do consumers want?'' As changes in demographics and lifestyles accelerate, consumer behavior is becoming increasingly difficult to predict. More people are surfing the Web, fewer are watching the tube. And a many are becoming more skeptical toward advertising in
title: TALKING SHOP WITH: Zoe Lazarus and Richard Welch; Hunting for the Next Cool in Advertising

body: Manhattan TRIBECA $1.37 million 53 North Moore Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,887-sq.-ft. condo in a renovated pre-World War II loft building; 24-hr. doormen; private elevator, gallery hallway, dining area, renovated chef's kitchen with dishwasher, renovated bathroom, custom closets and two walk-in closets, beamed ceilings, hardwood floors, oversize
title: Residential Sales

body: AS the New York City housing market flourished in much of the period between 1999 and 2002, the pace of apartment deregulation quickened in the most desirable neighborhoods of Manhattan and market rents rose sharply in much of the city, especially in Brooklyn and Queens, where median rents exceed $1,000 for the first time in some neighborhoods.
title: As Rents Rise, So Does Deregulation

body: With his beefy arms, booming voice and bristly crew cut, Joseph Attianese doesn't immediately remind people of a petite 25-year-old woman from the Midwest. In his 38 years, he has always lived in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. And he is certainly not feminine. But in recent weeks, just blocks from his home, a petite 25-year-old woman from the Midwest
title: A Play on Words; Brooklyn Accents and Trends Are Central to One-Woman Show

body: I MOVED back to New York in July, after three and half years in the politely repressed kingdom of Connecticut, where you just don't touch people. Not unless there is a reason that both parties, if asked, would call ''good.'' But in New York, that kingdom of self-absorbed passive aggression, I've been forced to relearn the art of a well-placed
title: URBAN STUDIES/JOUSTING; On the Teeming Sidewalks, Nudge, Counternudge

body: On the steps of City Hall, on public affairs television programs and in the offices of civic organizations and political parties, the chatter these days dwells on a single topic: nonpartisan elections. The referendum to end party primaries and make party affiliation an afterthought in local races has so dominated conversations that it is referred
title: Facing Vote to Alter Primaries, Many New Yorkers Just Yawn

body: To the Editor: Re ''The Two World of Justin Moore'' (Oct. 19), about the two lives of a young rock musician: As I looked at the front of the City section, I thought, ''I know that face.'' Indeed I do. I read on to learn that Justin Moore works at Mail Boxes, Etc., in Greenwich Village where I recently bought bubble wrap and handed him a few bucks
title: You Never Know Who'll Become a Star

body: The people have spoken. The Grocery, a small neighborhood restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, scored a Zagat food rating high enough to put it in seventh place on the list of New York's top restaurants, right up there with Le Bernardin, Daniel, Jean Georges and Bouley. What's wrong with this picture? At the moment, the Grocery has a rating of
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; On Second Thought: It's Great for Its Kind

body: Here, in order, are the seven best restaurants in New York City, according to food ratings in the 2004 Zagat Survey published today: Le Bernardin, Daniel, Peter Luger, Nobu, Bouley, Jean Georges and the Grocery. The Grocery? You may be forgiven for asking. The restaurant is a modest 30-seat, one-room storefront on Smith Street between Union and
title: A Little Restaurant Elbows the 4-Stars In Zagat's New List

body: EVENTS CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK GRADUATE CENTER, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street. Today at 2 p.m., a discussion about Woodrow Wilson and World War I with Thomas Fleming, a historian and author of ''The Illusion of Victory: America in World War I''; fee, $10; free for faculty and students. Tonight at 7, a free reading and discussion of
title: SPARE TIMES

body: WE are a city of heroes. The rest of the country may clamor for po' boys and hoagies, grinders, subs, wedges or torpedoes, but New York knows what really constitutes a gigantic sandwich, and what raises the hero above those pretenders; what makes it gastronomic royalty. Let there be no misunderstanding by those who have never ventured to New York,
title: Hey, Po' Boy, Meet Some Real Heroes

body: FEW New Yorkers brag about turning 40, but in China it is a reason to celebrate. Simpson Wong was the honored guest on a soft Wednesday night at his sister and brother-in-law's brownstone duplex in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. And as the birthday boy, he was not allowed to touch a pot, even though he is the chef and an owner of the sleek American
title: GOOD COMPANY; Shark Fin With 40 Candles

body: IT is a yellowish ribbon. And it is tied around the trunk of a tree in the sidewalk in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, where Court Street is crossed by numbered places, First Place, Second Place and so on. The ribbon is narrow and weatherworn and tied tightly, with a double knot a Boy Scout might use, not a very pretty one. It has no bow, no ruffle, no
title: URBAN STUDIES/WEATHERING; Amid the Bows, One Ragged Survivor

body: One is backed by several of the borough's major cultural institutions. The other was assembled on a kitchen table by a plucky Fort Greene resident who used three months' worth of rent to produce the first issue. Both are glossy quarterlies that made their debut last month and aim to capture affluent readers in brownstone Brooklyn, a task that other
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; For the Brownstone Set, Two Glossies Make a Pitch

body: Two years after the Sept. 11 attacks, two-thirds of New Yorkers say Arab-Americans, Muslims and immigrants from the Middle East are still likely to be unfairly singled out, according to the latest New York Times Poll. That sentiment is stronger among those who count Arabs among their close friends. Typical of those who think Arabs are targets for
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; There's Still a Chill in New York For Arab-Americans, Poll Says

body: WHEN the economy slows, the restaurants retreat. Except for a few publicity-seeking barkers who choose a slow moment to hawk their Kobe beef hot dogs and caviar burritos, the luxury ingredients have largely given way to the basics: pizza, burgers, sandwiches and the rest. Still, it would not be New York if restaurateurs did not apply at least a
title: $25 AND UNDER; Meeting Low Expectations, Happily

body: More than a million New York City students return this morning to a public school system shaken by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's far-reaching overhaul, with many teachers and parents already reporting confusion and disarray. At Thomas A. Edison High School in Jamaica, Queens, a teacher complained yesterday that the staff was ordered to use the
title: Back to Class, With Chaos Beyond Usual

body: The four-story brownstone in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, seemed perfect for Asian women who needed a place to hide from violent husbands and boyfriends while they contemplated their next move. It was a safe, quiet place, in an area far from where the women had lived and might be recognized. But some of the local residents are strongly opposed to the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; A Haven for Battered Women Ends Up in the Eye of a Storm

body: A New York City employee responsible for ferreting out tax violations has been charged with taking a bribe to lower the bill for a restaurant under investigation for suspected tax evasion, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said yesterday. The city employee, Losiny Sirleaf, an investigator for the Department of Finance, asked for a cut of whatever
title: City Tax Investigator Is Charged With Taking a Bribe to Help a Restaurant Under Scrutiny

body: New Yorkers with cars have access to suburban nurseries that might stock something more than ho-hum impatiens and curbside petunias. Now the Gowanus Nursery, which has opened in a part of Brooklyn that could be called Carroll Gardens Adjacent, is drawing even suburbanites for its species lilies and bold variegated aralia with six-foot leaves.
title: CURRENTS: NURSERIES; Now, Lilies and Sedums Grow in Brooklyn

body: One morning last week, Zoe Klein, a 24-year-old circus performer from Brooklyn, stood practicing her act, which involved swinging a pair of tethered balls, and stared out to the Hudson River. ''Growing up in New York, I always felt boxed in,'' she said. ''I always knew we were surrounded by water, but it always felt dirty or inaccessible.''
title: Going Near the Water; Renovation Efforts Reclaim the City's Forbidden Shoreline

body: It might seem that there have been only three kinds of days in New York in the summer of 2003: ''too rainy to go to the beach'' days, ''too soggy to do much at work'' days and, to use a nonscientific term, bad hair days. Actually, though, there have been four kinds of days. In a summer of drip-dry weather -- and after more than 37 inches of rain in
title: A Perfect Summer, if You're a Fungus; Record Rainfall Transforms City Into a Wonderland of Mushrooms

body: The opening of the new musical ''Lost'' at the New York International Fringe Festival on Saturday was peculiar in several ways. First, the curtain rose just past noon, a result of the festival's packed scheduling. Even as the finale played, another audience was milling in the humid lobby of the Linhart Theater, a third-floor black box in the East
title: Premiere Draws A Crowd, And Tears, For Absent Composer

author: Mark Rotella, an editor at Publishers Weekly, is the author of ''Stolen Figs: And Other Adventures in Calabria,'' published last month by North Point Press.
body: TO me, nothing is more comforting than a glass of Montepulciano and a bowl of spaghetti and meatballs. At the end of the workweek, I like to relax, to eat with friends at a place that feels like home, one where I will be greeted by the maître d', who, although he doesn't know me, will treat me as if he does. And for someone like me, an
title: Simply Red

body: Six years ago, to the delight of Downtown Brooklyn residents, the city agreed to a so-called traffic-calming study to unravel gridlock. It was billed as a model project that might bring zigzags and other unfamiliar traffic innovations to the clogged streets in and around Downtown. But in late June, at the conclusion of the $1.2 million study, the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ROADWAYS; In Brooklyn, Gridlock About Gridlock Spells Anger

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Made in the Bronx Q. I recently came across a passing reference to the dome of the United States Capitol that said it had been created in the Bronx and then shipped to Washington. Can you fill in some details? A. Not only was one of the most visible icons of American democracy built in the Bronx, the company that was awarded the contract opened a
title: F.Y.I.

body: This Is Not a Pipe Q. While attending a performance at Town Hall recently, I could not help admiring the two handsome rows of organ pipes that flank the stage. I was somewhat mystified, however, because the hall does not appear to have an organ console. As I studied the pipes more closely, they began to dissolve before my eyes into something not
title: F.Y.I.

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement. body: Around the Fourth of July, residents of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, are used to hearing firecrackers. But they were unprepared for a string of fires that destroyed three cars in the first week of this month. Residents are still mystified about the fires, which have prompted speculation about road rage and anti-gentrification vandalism. In the early
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; Burning Rubber, and the Rest of the Car, Too

body: Sitting on a rickety stool in the basement of St. Thomas's Church at 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue, a messenger bag bulging with sheet music at his feet, Aaron Sunstein, 16, had something he wanted to share. Reaching into a front pocket of his jeans, he produced a set of keys, a jangling mass of metal worthy of a building superintendent's tool belt.
title: Fledgling Organists Go to Church to Learn

body: The sidewalks of New York have their own song. Broadway has several. Well-known plays and movies have been set in or inspired by, among many other New York locations, the Waldorf, the Plaza, Wall Street, Macy's, Yankee Stadium, Tiffany & Company, Katz's Delicatessen and the late Cammareri Brothers Bakery in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. But for all
title: TUNNEL VISION; Ballet for Subway? Well, It Already Has Conductors

body: Because of an editing error, an article on June 9 about the 20th-anniversary celebration of the Marco Polo Ristorante in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, which was attended by a man said to be Marco Polo's last living descendant, misidentified the pope who authorized Polo's mission to the court of the Mongol emperor Kublai Khan around 1271. He was
title: Corrections

body: Over the years, New Yorkers have tried a variety of tactics to assert their right to park in front of their homes. They have illegally painted curbs yellow; they have dragged Dumpsters and concrete-filled trash cans into the street; they have stood in parking spaces, waving away drivers. Now, by way of Boston, Los Angeles and Pittsburgh, comes a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK PARKING; In the Jostle for a Parking Spot, Living Nearby May Add Some Muscle

body: A restaurant trade group charged yesterday that the city was hurting New York restaurants with higher fines and arbitrary new health inspections. The group, the New York State Restaurant Association, said in a lawsuit filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn that the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene adopted the new rules
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Restaurants Protest New Rules

body: It all started out as a bit of a lark. To generate a little buzz about the 20th anniversary celebration of the Marco Polo Ristorante in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, the owner, Joe Chirico, and a public relations consultant thought they would try to find a relative of the great traveler himself who might be persuaded to come. They did not have great
title: Finding China, on a Brooklyn Table; A Kinsman of Marco Polo Eats Italian in Carroll Gardens

body: About six months ago, Karen Cooper, who is the director of Film Forum on West Houston Street, ordered a print of a little-known documentary titled ''Spellbound.'' The film follows eight children as they spell their way into the 1999 National Spelling Bee, and while Ms. Cooper found the film heartwarming, she didn't expect crowds. Then something
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOHO; Spellers Struggle on Screen. Hipsters Howl and Mimic.

body: HIGHLIGHTS IBSEN IN BROOKLYN -- Scholars from 21 countries and dignitaries like Knut Vollebaek, Norway's ambassador to the United States, will gather at 10 a.m. today on the Brooklyn Campus of Long Island University for the 10th International Ibsen Conference. Convened every three to four years and previously held in the United States only in 1989
title: ARTS BRIEFING

body: EVENTS NEW YORK IRANIAN FILM FESTIVAL, Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village. A series of contemporary films continues through Sunday. Screenings tonight at 7:30 and 9:30; tomorrow at 5:30, 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.; and Sunday at 5:15, 7:15 and 9:30 p.m. Admission: $8; $5 for students. Information: (212) 505-5181.

body: HIGHLIGHTS DYLAN TALKS TO SCORSESE -- Bob Dylan is to be interviewed by Martin Scorsese for a documentary that will examine the singer's early career and the cultural and political impact of his music. The BBC, which will finance the production in part, said yesterday that the film would have its premiere on its network and in the United States on
title: ARTS BRIEFING

body: THERE are 120 acres of the Brooklyn waterfront that Sabato F. Catucci calls his own. The big orange and red containers, the huge forklifts, the warehouses, the enormous wood-paneled office with leather furniture and the collection of carved bald eagles are spread around him like toys. This is Mr. Catucci's world. It has been his world for more than
title: PUBLIC LIVES; For King of Brooklyn Docks, It's All About Family

body: TO be responsible for the design of the 2,702 buildings of the New York City Housing Authority is a little like putting bow ties on a flock of ugly chickens. But that is David J. Burney's job. As the agency's director of design and capital improvement, he spends about $500 million a year to maintain and improve the city's public housing stock. Mr.
title: URBAN TACTICS; The People's Architect

body: To the Editor: In the article ''My Brother, the Licensed Know-It-All'' (May 11), the supposedly learned New York tour guide refers to the seven secrets of ''Grand Central Station.'' As any tour guide should know, the proper name is Grand Central Terminal, or just ''Grand Central.'' Larry Resick Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn
title: The Mysteries Of Max's; Terminal, Please, Not Station

body: A former New York City police detective who was convicted of helping to impede the investigation of a 1998 mob murder was sentenced yesterday to 12 and a half years in federal prison. Judge Michael B. Mukasey of Federal District Court in Manhattan sentenced the former detective, Michael Silvestri, to slightly less time than prosecutors had
title: Former Detective Is Sentenced In Coverup of 1998 Mob Murder

body: My favorite thing in Montero's is the little working model of a steam engine, greasy and coated with dust, on a ledge up above where the cigarette machine used to be. It's a foot high, 18 inches or so long, jet black, with six vertical pistons. Flick the switch hidden behind the black-and-white photograph of the two Danish seamen standing outside
title: MY BROOKLYN; A Raffish Reminder, Landlubbers, of Saltier Days

body: When Charlene De Luca leaves her ancestral brownstone in Carroll Gardens in July, Brooklyn will be 725 pairs of shoes poorer. That's O.K., because her sister Paula, who lives down the street, has 1,100 pairs and no immediate plans to leave the neighborhood. The Brooklyn Shoe Sisters, though divided by Charlene's forthcoming move to Florida with her
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; Footnotes: Two Sisters Have Hundreds of Shoes With Which to Mark Their Days

body: In 1937, when Frank Sacco opened Frank's Department Store on Union Street near Columbia Street, he could not have predicted that he would one day have as a neighbor a snack bar with the trendy made-up name of Schnäk. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; On a Street That Once Bustled, New Shops and Bakeries Blossom

body: The city has hired a consultant to study uses for approximately 100 acres of Red Hook waterfront that now serve as Brooklyn's last active port, raising the possibility that the site will become a park, a museum or luxury housing. title: Leaseholders at Brooklyn Port Worry What Study May Bring

body: The Burger Variations Rare, in the Shelburne Hotel, 303 Lexington Avenue (37th Street), may be the most elegant burger spot in town. Glen Coben, the architect, has used plush fabrics and sleek woods, and the burgers on brioche rolls ($7.50 to $21.50) include some with seafood and turkey. ''Most people want medium-rare,'' Douglas Boxer, a partner,
title: OFF THE MENU

body: THE man in the black knit cap wanted to break the bad news, but first he had to out-shout the guy on the saxophone. ''We're going to have to find a new place,'' the man in the cap, Alex Saavedra, bellowed glumly to a visitor at Uncle Joe's, a tiny bar nestled among the warehouses downtown here. ''They're turning Wednesdays into House Night.'' Mr.
title: Hip Yet Prospering. Can Jersey City Do It?

body: To the Editor: I'm glad to see I'm not the only one with a soft spot for Downing Stadium, the ontime ballpark on Randalls Island under the Triborough Bridge (''Not-Moses Stadium,'' F.Y.I., March 23). I had so many good times there that I wrote an admittedly bad poem about it 20 years ago. Here is one stanza: ''With dimensions PoloGroundic/And the
title: Downing Stadium, Not Quite Forgotten

body: To the Editor: Re ''Frisson of Unease Among the City French'' (March 23): So the French consulate thinks that ''most New Yorkers support France's position and are against the war.'' I know many people who, like me, are against this war, but I know nobody who would ''support France's position.'' That's because France's stand has been perceived as
title: At the Very Least, Don't Rename Those Fries

body: A Roman Catholic priest was sentenced yesterday to four months in jail for molesting a 12-year-old altar girl at her home in Brooklyn in 1999. The case against the priest, the Rev. Francis X. Nelson, was the first sexual abuse prosecution completed in New York City based on old files turned over to prosecutors by the Brooklyn Diocese last year.
title: Priest Gets Four Months In Molesting Of Altar Girl

body: Monday morning, and Jennifer Logan's second graders are banging tambourines, shaking maracas and chanting their rhyme of the day: If you can spell thing, you can spell sting. If you can spell sting, you can spell ring. If you can spell ring, you can spell spring. If you can spell spring, you can spell bring. B-R-I-N-G, cha-cha-cha! This is a
title: A Living Lab for the City's New Curriculum

body: To the Editor: Re ''Anxiety Rides the A Train'' (Coping, by Anemona Hartocollis, Feb. 23): I suppose many people out there in the sprawl think the New York subway is a scary place in the best of times and prefer the illusion of freedom that the automobile provides but all of us pay for dearly. Jane Harman, the Representative from California, was
title: Subway Riders Don't Need A Scare From California

title: Priest Convicted of Molesting Girl, 12, at Her Home in 1999

title: THREATS AND RESPONSES: NEW YORK; Disagreements on Specifics, but Unanimity That There's No Going Back

author: Ross B. Intelisano is a lawyer.
body: Beginning today, New Yorkers must dial 1, plus the area code, plus the seven-digit telephone number, to complete any local telephone call made within or between New York City boroughs. That's 11 digits in total, whether the call is from Manhattan to Manhattan or Brooklyn to Queens. The Federal Communications Commission says this change will
title: Ending the 212 Clique

body: Brasserie, Plus Sushi The French brasserie formula can be seen in restaurants all over town: tile and mirrors, Belle Époque or Art Deco lighting, and menus offering plateaux de fruits de mer and steak frites. Brasserie 360, 200 East 60th Street, as designed by Morris Nathanson, has that look, but it promises to be more than just another trendy
title: OFF THE MENU

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will announce today the 10 regional superintendents for the overhauled Department of Education. At least five who are expected to be named are widely respected community school district superintendents and four of those currently oversee relatively high-performing districts. Shelley Harwayne of District 2 in Manhattan,
title: Mayor to Name 10 to Lead Overhaul of Public Schools

body: AMONG the many improbable things to know about Julia Glass is that she never even wanted to come to the city that is at the center of her novel. Just out of Yale and working at a Harvard museum, ''I was determined not to be one more artist in New York,'' she said. But the museum job soured, friends beckoned and maybe some things are just
title: Metro Matters; Author's Life, Made of Twists And Turns
